urls.title: Building stories with data: Automating sentences with R
urls.description: A short description of the post.

tweets.text:
For more on automating sentences in #rstats, here's a blog post I wrote a while ago. 

All the text in the post's image is generated straight from the data. 
https://t.co/4YIZMFQT4g

this might be a stupid #Rstats question...
how can i have my #R script open while also being able to see my dataframe? i often want to write some syntax while looking at the dataframe; would be easier to have them both visible (i.e., not toggle back and forth).
@LaurenKOlinger @rstats_tweets Thanks! I didn‚Äôt realize I could add a column and make that my script!
@vaidya_jg @rstats_tweets *pane

A big thank you to our @meanwhileina & all attendees of the NEXT STEPS IN APPLIED BAYESIAN REGRESSION MODELING course! üôèüéâ 

It was such a fun and informative week, and we gained valuable insights into advanced techniques that¬¥ll elevate our bayesian modeling skills.üíØüöÄ
#Rstats https://t.co/BKG7HybS5n

urls.title: The Human Protein Atlas
urls.description: The Human Protein Atlas project is funded by the Knut & Alice Wallenberg foundation.

tweets.text: If you get a list of marker genes from your single-cell data, https://t.co/ZhAiX8VU7k can be very helpful to get a general idea of what cell type it is.

Been using VSCode for a two weeks now and it's great! üëå

But when it comes to R, nothing beats RStudio.

So, I've settled on the following workflow for now: RStudio for R. VSCode for everything else üôå #rstats

https://t.co/o34tFYBTVa

This week's #TidyTuesday was very topical - looking at different time zones around the world üåç

Each point represents the principal location of a different time zone listed in the IANA time zone database üïìüï£üïò

Code: https://t.co/YVrvWUKxxt

#RStats #R4DS #DataViz https://t.co/OLFHKVylu5

I'm thinking about moving from RStudio to VSCode.

#rstats folks: What are good resources to make the transition as smooth as possible? Any obstacles I should be aware of?

urls.title: Writing a reproducible paper with RStudio and Quarto
urls.description: This paper provides a template to write a reproducible scientific paper with RStudio and Quarto. It falls into a series on other templates, namely on RMarkdown and pagedown that can be downloaded here (Bauer and Landesvatter 2018) and here (Bauer and Landesvatter 2021). Below we outline some of the ‚Äútricks‚Äù/code (e.g., referencing tables, sections etc.) we had to figure out to produce this document. The underlying files which produce this document can be downloaded here. We are convinced that in the future there will be many improvements and developments with regards to RStudio and Quarto. We intend to update this file when we discover more convenient code. You can follow any updates on the github repository.

tweets.text: Want to write a reproducible manuscript with Quarto and RStudio but not sure where to start? @p_c_bauer  and I have created a template that simplifies starting and allows you to focus on the content ‚úçÔ∏è https://t.co/TPj1mMsFBB #scientificwriting #quarto #RMarkdown
